div.head: Gen. Grant's Official Report of the Battle of Fort Donelson
div.summary: Reprints General Grant's report of the battle at Fort Donelson, including general orders congratulating the troops and the officers present at the battle.

div.head: Rebel Account of the Fall of Bowling Green
div.summary: Report of occurrences at the fall of Bowling Green from an eye-witness to the event.

page.pageNote: Advertisements, columns 1 and 2; a tribute to Willie Lincoln, the son of the President who died of pneumonia the previous week, column 5

div.head: Whom Shall We Believe?
div.summary: Asks which is to be believed--the Valley Spirit, which claims injury against the South was the cause of secession, or the Richmond Whig, which claims that Southern leaders brought the South into the rebellion for no reason.

div.head: The True Spirit of the South
div.summary: Argues that there are many in the South who desire to rejoin the United States.

div.head: Who Is to Blame?
div.excerpt: "Whatever the preservation of the Union may cost in life and treasure--and it has cost already a fearful amount of both--the faithful historian will lay the responsibility of the whole on the shoulders of prominent men who led and controlled the Democratic party."
div.summary: Answers the Spirit's complaint that the war is costing the government "at least one thousand millions of dollars" with the arguments that the preservation of the Union is worth whatever the cost and that it is the Democrats' fault that the war in the first place.

div.head: A Ring of the True Metal
div.summary: Prints the proclamation of Commodore Foot to the residents of Clarksville at Fort Donelson notifying them that no person or property shall be disturbed as long as military equipment is surrendered and neither the "Secession flag" nor sentiments of secession are displayed.

div.head: More Returned Prisoners
div.summary: Reports that more Union officers have been returned to Baltimore from Fortress Monroe.

div.head: Capture of Nashville Confirmed
div.summary: Reports that Union troops have taken possession of Nashville, and rumors claim that Memphis has also surrendered.

page.pageNote: News printed in Southern newspapers, column 4; proceedings of Congress, columns 4 and 5; advertisements, column 5

div.head: Our Boys Have Moved
div.summary: Reports that the brigade containing the 77th Pennsylvania have left Green River, Kentucky, where they have camped for the past three months, and are headed, it is presumed, toward Nashville, Tennessee.

div.head: Important Order
div.summary: Reports that Secretary of War Stanton has issued a proclamation announcing that the government has taken control of the telegraph lines and that nothing relating to the movement of government troops is to be published without the prior approval of the proper authorities. The Dispatch endorses this action.

div.head: Important War Bulletin
div.summary: The orders issued by Secretary Stanton pertaining to the seizure of all telegraph lines by the government.

div.head: Deaths
div.summary: Mr. David Wilson, about 70 years of age, died of dropsy on February 27 in St. Thomas township. The Dispatch reports that Mr. Wilson was one of the wealthiest citizens of the county.

page.pageNote: Incidents from the battle of Fort Donelson that denote the defiance demonstrated by individual Southern soldiers as well as the "Union recklessness of life," column 2; advertisements, columns 3-5

div.head: An Appeal from the Rebel Commissioners
div.summary: Correspondence between Queen Victoria's Secretary of Foreign Affairs--Lord Russell--and the "rebel commissioners" Yancey, Rost, and Mann. The Confederate officers attempt to persuade Britain to recognize the Confederacy as a nation, and Lord Russell declares the Queen's decision to preserve Britain's neutrality.
